natural problem: Sides $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{EF}$ of regular hexagon $ABCDEF$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$?
natural solution: The sum of the angle measures of a hexagon is $180(6-2) = 720$ degrees, so each angle of a regular hexagon measures $720^\circ/6=120^\circ$.
Therefore, $\angle BAF = 120^\circ$, which means $\angle FAP = 180^\circ - \angle BAF = 60^\circ$.

Similarly, $\angle PFA = 60^\circ$. Since the angles of $\triangle APF$ sum to $180^\circ$, we have $\angle APF = 180^\circ - 60^\circ - 60^\circ = \boxed{60^\circ}$. [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,P;

A = (1,0); B = rotate(60)*A; C=rotate(60)*B; D = rotate(60)*C; EE = rotate(60)*D; F = rotate(60)*EE; P = A + (A - B); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--A--P--F,linewidth(1)); label("$A$",A,NE); label("$B$",B,N);

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes AB EF P :: real
assumes h0 : "AB = EF"
and h1 : "P = AB + EF"
shows  "P = 60"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{EF}$ of regular hexagon $ABCDEF$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of a hexagon is $180(6-2) = 720$ degrees, so each angle of a regular hexagon measures $720^\circ/6=120^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BAF = 120^\circ$, which means $\angle FAP = 180^\circ - \angle BAF = 60^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PFA = 60^\circ$. Since the angles of $\triangle APF$ sum to $180^\circ$, we have $\angle APF = 180^\circ - 60^\circ - 60^\circ = \boxed{60^\circ}$. [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,P;
 A = (1,0); B = rotate(60)*A; C=rotate(60)*B; D = rotate(60)*C; EE = rotate(60)*D; F = rotate(60)*EE; P = A + (A - B); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--A--P--F,linewidth(1)); label("$A$",A,NE); label("$B$",B,N);
 label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",EE,S); label("$F$",F,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes AB EF P :: real
assumes h0 : "AB = EF"
and h1 : "P = AB + EF"
shows  "P = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that the lengths of segments AB and EF are equal, and the perimeter P of a figure is the sum of the lengths of AB and EF. If P equals 60, what is the length of AB (or EF)?

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B E F P :: point
assumes h0 : "regular_hexagon A B C D E F"
and h1 : "extended_line A B P"
and h2 : "extended_line E F P"
shows  "angle_measure A P F = 60"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{EF}$ of regular hexagon $ABCDEF$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of a hexagon is $180(6-2) = 720$ degrees, so each angle of a regular hexagon measures $720^\circ/6=120^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BAF = 120^\circ$, which means $\angle FAP = 180^\circ - \angle BAF = 60^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PFA = 60^\circ$. Since the angles of $\triangle APF$ sum to $180^\circ$, we have $\angle APF = 180^\circ - 60^\circ - 60^\circ = \boxed{60^\circ}$. [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,P;
 A = (1,0); B = rotate(60)*A; C=rotate(60)*B; D = rotate(60)*C; EE = rotate(60)*D; F = rotate(60)*EE; P = A + (A - B); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--A--P--F,linewidth(1)); label("$A$",A,NE); label("$B$",B,N);
 label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",EE,S); label("$F$",F,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B E F P :: point
assumes h0 : "regular_hexagon A B C D E F"
and h1 : "extended_line A B P"
and h2 : "extended_line E F P"
shows  "angle_measure A P F = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a regular hexagon ABCDEF, extend lines AB and EF to a point P. What is the measure of angle APF? The answer is 60 degrees.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E F P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "is_regular_hexagon A B C D E F"
and h1 : "P = extend_line A B intersect extend_line E F"
shows  "angle P = 60"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{EF}$ of regular hexagon $ABCDEF$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of a hexagon is $180(6-2) = 720$ degrees, so each angle of a regular hexagon measures $720^\circ/6=120^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BAF = 120^\circ$, which means $\angle FAP = 180^\circ - \angle BAF = 60^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PFA = 60^\circ$. Since the angles of $\triangle APF$ sum to $180^\circ$, we have $\angle APF = 180^\circ - 60^\circ - 60^\circ = \boxed{60^\circ}$. [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,P;
 A = (1,0); B = rotate(60)*A; C=rotate(60)*B; D = rotate(60)*C; EE = rotate(60)*D; F = rotate(60)*EE; P = A + (A - B); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--A--P--F,linewidth(1)); label("$A$",A,NE); label("$B$",B,N);
 label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",EE,S); label("$F$",F,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E F P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "is_regular_hexagon A B C D E F"
and h1 : "P = extend_line A B intersect extend_line E F"
shows  "angle P = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a regular hexagon ABCDEF, let P be the point where the extension of side AB intersects with the extension of side EF. What is the measure of ∠APF? The final answer is 60 degrees.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B E F P :: "real_2" and deg :: "real_2 \<Rightarrow> real_2 \<Rightarrow> real_2 \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "is_regular_hexagon A B _ _ E F"
and h1 : "extended_line_intersect A B E F = Some P"
shows  "deg A P B = 60"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{EF}$ of regular hexagon $ABCDEF$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of a hexagon is $180(6-2) = 720$ degrees, so each angle of a regular hexagon measures $720^\circ/6=120^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BAF = 120^\circ$, which means $\angle FAP = 180^\circ - \angle BAF = 60^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PFA = 60^\circ$. Since the angles of $\triangle APF$ sum to $180^\circ$, we have $\angle APF = 180^\circ - 60^\circ - 60^\circ = \boxed{60^\circ}$. [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,P;
 A = (1,0); B = rotate(60)*A; C=rotate(60)*B; D = rotate(60)*C; EE = rotate(60)*D; F = rotate(60)*EE; P = A + (A - B); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--A--P--F,linewidth(1)); label("$A$",A,NE); label("$B$",B,N);
 label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",EE,S); label("$F$",F,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B E F P :: "real_2" and deg :: "real_2 \<Rightarrow> real_2 \<Rightarrow> real_2 \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "is_regular_hexagon A B _ _ E F"
and h1 : "extended_line_intersect A B E F = Some P"
shows  "deg A P B = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given that A, B, E, and F are the vertices of a regular hexagon with the extended lines AB and EF intersecting at point P, prove that the angle APB is 60 degrees.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P A B E F :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "regular_hexagon A B E F"
and h1 : "extended_line_to_meet_at_point P A B E F"
shows  "angle P = 60"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{EF}$ of regular hexagon $ABCDEF$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of a hexagon is $180(6-2) = 720$ degrees, so each angle of a regular hexagon measures $720^\circ/6=120^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BAF = 120^\circ$, which means $\angle FAP = 180^\circ - \angle BAF = 60^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PFA = 60^\circ$. Since the angles of $\triangle APF$ sum to $180^\circ$, we have $\angle APF = 180^\circ - 60^\circ - 60^\circ = \boxed{60^\circ}$. [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,P;

 label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",EE,S); label("$F$",F,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes P A B E F :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "regular_hexagon A B E F"
and h1 : "extended_line_to_meet_at_point P A B E F"
shows  "angle P = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a regular hexagon with vertices A, B, E, and F, if a line is extended from point A through point B to meet at point P outside the hexagon, then the angle at point P is 60 degrees.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E F P :: "real \<times> real" and angle_P :: real
assumes h0 : "is_regular_hexagon A B C D E F"
and h1 : "P = extend_line AB EF"
shows  "angle_P = 60"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{EF}$ of regular hexagon $ABCDEF$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of a hexagon is $180(6-2) = 720$ degrees, so each angle of a regular hexagon measures $720^\circ/6=120^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BAF = 120^\circ$, which means $\angle FAP = 180^\circ - \angle BAF = 60^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PFA = 60^\circ$. Since the angles of $\triangle APF$ sum to $180^\circ$, we have $\angle APF = 180^\circ - 60^\circ - 60^\circ = \boxed{60^\circ}$. [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,P;

 label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",EE,S); label("$F$",F,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E F P :: "real \<times> real" and angle_P :: real
assumes h0 : "is_regular_hexagon A B C D E F"
and h1 : "P = extend_line AB EF"
shows  "angle_P = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: If $A, B, C, D, E, F$ form a regular hexagon, and $P$ is a point on the line extended from line $AB$ through point $EF$, then the angle at point $P$ is $60$ degrees.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B E F P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "regular_hexagon A B C D E F"
and h1 : "extended_line A B P"
and h2 : "extended_line E F P"
shows  "degree_measure P = 60"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{EF}$ of regular hexagon $ABCDEF$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 60^\circ

 The sum of the angle measures of a hexagon is $180(6-2) = 720$ degrees, so each angle of a regular hexagon measures $720^\circ/6=120^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BAF = 120^\circ$, which means $\angle FAP = 180^\circ - \angle BAF = 60^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PFA = 60^\circ$. Since the angles of $\triangle APF$ sum to $180^\circ$, we have $\angle APF = 180^\circ - 60^\circ - 60^\circ = \boxed{60^\circ}$. [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,P;

theorem
fixes A B E F P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "regular_hexagon A B C D E F"
and h1 : "extended_line A B P"
and h2 : "extended_line E F P"
shows  "degree_measure P = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given that A, B, C, D, E, F form a regular hexagon and that P lies on the extended line AB and also on the extended line EF, what is the degree measure of P? The final answer is 60 degrees.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes AB EF :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "AB = EF"
and h1 : "ABCDEF is regular hexagon"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = angle ABCDEF"
shows  "P = 60"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{EF}$ of regular hexagon $ABCDEF$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of a hexagon is $180(6-2) = 720$ degrees, so each angle of a regular hexagon measures $720^\circ/6=120^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BAF = 120^\circ$, which means $\angle FAP = 180^\circ - \angle BAF = 60^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PFA = 60^\circ$. Since the angles of $\triangle APF$ sum to $180^\circ$, we have $\angle APF = 180^\circ - 60^\circ - 60^\circ = \boxed{60^\circ}$. [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,P;
 A = (1,0); B = rotate(60)*A; C=rotate(60)*B; D = rotate(60)*C; EE = rotate(60)*D; F = rotate(60)*EE; P = A + (A - B); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--A--P--F,linewidth(1)); label("$A$",A,NE); label("$B$",B,N);
 label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",EE,S); label("$F$",F,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes AB EF :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "AB = EF"
and h1 : "ABCDEF is regular hexagon"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = angle ABCDEF"
shows  "P = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: If ABCDEF is a regular hexagon and AB equals EF, what is the measure of each interior angle? The final answer is 60 degrees.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B E F P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "regular_hexagon A B C D E F"
and h1 : "extended A B P"
and h2 : "extended E F P"
shows  "angle P = 60"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{EF}$ of regular hexagon $ABCDEF$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of a hexagon is $180(6-2) = 720$ degrees, so each angle of a regular hexagon measures $720^\circ/6=120^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BAF = 120^\circ$, which means $\angle FAP = 180^\circ - \angle BAF = 60^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PFA = 60^\circ$. Since the angles of $\triangle APF$ sum to $180^\circ$, we have $\angle APF = 180^\circ - 60^\circ - 60^\circ = \boxed{60^\circ}$. [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,P;

 label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",EE,S); label("$F$",F,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B E F P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "regular_hexagon A B C D E F"
and h1 : "extended A B P"
and h2 : "extended E F P"
shows  "angle P = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a regular hexagon ABCDEF, let P be a point on the extension of sides AB and EF. Prove that the angle at P measures 60 degrees.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B E F P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "is_regular_hexagon A B C D E F"
and h1 : "is_extended_line AB P"
and h2 : "is_extended_line EF P"
shows  "angle P = 60"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{EF}$ of regular hexagon $ABCDEF$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 60^\circ

 Therefore, $\angle BAF = 120^\circ$, which means $\angle FAP = 180^\circ - \angle BAF = 60^\circ$.

theorem
fixes A B E F P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "is_regular_hexagon A B C D E F"
and h1 : "is_extended_line AB P"
and h2 : "is_extended_line EF P"
shows  "angle P = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a regular hexagon ABCDEF, extend lines AB and EF to a point P. What is the measure of angle P? The final answer is 60 degrees.
